bioghist.p: Henry Kenneth Alfred Russell, known as Ken Russell, was a British film director. He was born in Southampton, Hampshire, England on 3 July 1927. He began making short films in the 1950s and made several documentaries for the BBC TV arts programme Monitor from 1959-1965. His 1969 film Women in Love , an adaptation of the D.H Lawrence novel, won him an Oscar nomination for Best Director. Several of Russell's films caused controversy for their nudity and portrayal of sexuality, The Devils (1971) probably causing the greatest furore. Other notable films include Tommy (1975) and Altered States (1980). Russell died on 27 November 2011 in Lymington, Hampshire, England.

scopecontent.p: The collection principally consists of still photographs taken on the sets of several of Russell's films; also included are scripts, videotapes, promotional materials for some of Russell's works, and miscellaneous other materials such as programmes for film festivals and film equipment (a light, a clapperboard, film tins).

arrangement.p: The collection is organised alphabetically by title of the production, with items unrelated to a production at the end. It is not known whether this was the original arrangement.

appraisal.p: All items in the collection are to be retained permanently.

processinfo.p: The biographical information was gathered from Encyclopaedia Britannica and the BFI's ScreenOnline (both of which were last accessed on 6 December 2022).

custodhist.p: The collection was donated by Ken Russell. The precise date of the donation has not been recorded, but it is likely to have around 2000, and is certainly no later than 2002.

accessrestrict.p: Access is by appointment only. Please email: library.support@solent.ac.uk

userestrict.p: The collection is copyright protected. It cannot be reproduced without consultation with the archive manager.

did.unittitle: Film, TV, Stage, and Radio Productions

scopecontent.p: Material relating to Russell's film, television, and radio works, principally consisting of still photographs taken on the sets of these works, but also including scripts and videotapes.

note.p: Most entries in this series include a printed page (from Film Index International, or IMDB) giving details of the production (date, crew, cast); some of these are dated (November 2000). It is assumed, but not known, that these were printed by repository staff when the collection was originally arranged.

scopecontent.p: Three black and white photographs related to Ken Russell's documentary The ABC of British Music , which was broadcast by London Weekend Television on February 4, 1988. Two photographs are of the filming process, and are attributed in pencil to Simon Farrell. The third could be a still from the film.

p.extref: IMDB page for The ABC of British Music

scopecontent.p: Items relating to the film Alice in Russialand , written and directed by Ken Russell.

Detailed contents:
- 3 typewritten scripts for Alice in Russialand , one dated 15.4.93.
- 1 shooting schedule, dated 15.4.93
- 20 colour slides appearing to show scenes from the film, and attributed to Daniel Meadows.

p.extref: IMDB page for Alice in Russialand

scopecontent.p: Items relating to Ken Russell's film Altered States .

Detailed contents:
- 12 miniature (approximately 30 X 25 cm) promotional posters for the film.
- 33 black and white photographs, 32 apparently stills from the film, 1 showing Russell on set.
- 34 colour photographic slides, apparently stills from the film.
Items relating to Ken Russell's 1971 musical comedy The Boyfriend , an adaptation of Sandy Wilson's 1953 musical of the same title.

Detailed contents:
- 72 black and white photographs, most apparently stills from the film, possibly some from the filming process, one showing Russell copyrighted to MGM 1972.
- a promotional booklet for the film.
Material relating to Ken Russell's film Billion Dollar Brain , an adaptation of Len Deighton's novel of the same title.

Detailed contents:
- 101 black and white photographs taken during filming and breaks from filming. Many are attributed to John Jay; some show Russell himself, most are of the actors; one shows Russell's wife, Shirley, with their three sons, and has a note to "Mama Russell" on the back.
- A promotional booklet ("Exhibitor's Campaign Book") for the film (11 pages)

p.extref: IMDB page for Billion Dollar Brain

scopecontent.p: Photographs showing Russell directing William and Dorothy , one of the episodes of Clouds of Glory .

p.extref: IMDB page for Clouds of Glory

scopecontent.p: Black and white photographs taken from the making of Russell's film Crimes of Passion . Most photographs appear to show scenes from the film, one shows Russell directing.

p.extref: IMDB page for Crimes of Passion

scopecontent.p: Black and white photographs relating to Russell's film Dante's Inferno , broadcast by the BBC on 22 December 1967 as part of the documentary series Omnibus . One photograph appears to be a still from the film; the others, some of which are attributed to George Konig, may have been taken during filming.
Four copies of scripts for The Death of Alexander Scriabin , a radio play by Ken Russell about the Russian composer and pianist, broadcast in June 1995 on BBC Radio 3.
Two photographs taken from the making of Russell's film Debussy .

Detailed contents:
- A photograph of Victoria Russell, Ken Russell's daughter, 18 months old, with the actor Oliver Reed.
- Apparently a photograph of a scene from the film.
Photographs relating to Russell's film The Devils .

Detailed contents:
92 sheets (each sheet with multiple photographs) of colour photographs taken from the filming process.
5 black and white photographs apparently showing stills from the film, 3 of which appear to be promotional material.

arrangement.p: Six of the sheets of photographs are held in the third (oversize) drawer in the cabinet.

scopecontent.p: Three black and white photographs taken during the filming of The Diary of a Nobody , Russell's film based on the novel by George and Weedon Grossmith.

p.extref: IMDB page for The Diary of a Nobody

scopecontent.p: A treatment by Ken Russell for an episode of The South Bank Show discussing the lives of composer's widows. The treatment is titled Double Exposure , but it was broadcast as Classic Widows by ITV on 5 February 1995.

A script (56 pages) for Elgar's Land of Hope , "a screen story by Ken Russell". It is dated 21 January 1976, and is to be distinguished from Russell's 1962 documentary about Elgar. It is unclear whether the script was ever made into a production.

24 black and white photographs relating to Ken Russell's film French Dressing , apparently including stills from the film and photographs taken on set, which are labelled "to be returned to Chris Wicking," possibly the photographer.
Photographs (6 colour, 3 black and white) taken from Ken Russell's film Gothic .
Three scripts of the film Immortal Beloved , written by Ken Russell and Jo Anderson.
Material relating to the 1995 short film The Insatiable Mrs. Kirsch , written by Ken Russell and Hetty Baynes.

Detailed contents:
- 5 copies of a script for the film
- 1 small envelope of negatives
- 27 colour transparencies of photographs taken during filming, showing both Russell and (apparently) scenes from the film, attributed to Mark Bourdillon.
- 159 colour slides taken during filming, showing both Russell and (apparently) scenes from the film, attributed to Stay Still.
- 1 colour photograph, apparently showing Russell and his family.

p.extref: IMDB page for The Insatiable Mrs. Kirsch

did.unittitle: Isadora Duncan, the Biggest Dancer in the World

scopecontent.p: 37 black and white photographs taken from Isadora Duncan, the Biggest Dancer in the World , also called Isadora , which was directed by Russell and broadcast by BBC TV in 1966.

p.extref: IMDB page for Isadora Duncan, the Biggest Dancer in the World

scopecontent.p: Material relating to Russell's film Lady Chatterley , including two black and white photographs of Russell, one with his son Rupert, on set, and two PAL VHS video cassettes (each 120 minutes, made by London Films).
Black and white and colour photographs taken from the making of Russell's film Lisztomania . At least one of the photographs is attributed, in pencil, to Simon Farrell.

Material relating to Ken Russell's film Mahler . There are 39 black and white photographs that appear to have been taken during film-making, some possibly showing scenes from the film; some are attributed to Frank Connor. There is also a promotional booklet for the film.

arrangement.p: The booklet is in the third, oversize, drawer in the cabinet.

scopecontent.p: Twelve black and white photographs apparently taken during the filming of some of Russell's works. It has not been possible to identify the works for these items.
2 copies extended treatment for Ming-Ti: The Lowlander , "the first 25 minute episode in the 12 part series by Ken Russell." There is no external evidence to suggest that this was ever produced.
Material relating to Russell's film The Music Lovers .

Detailed contents:
- 8 colour photographs, apparently promotional stills.
- 6 black and white photographs taken during filming.
- 3 promotional booklets for the film, one in French, one labelled "Exhibitor's Campaign Book".

p.extref: IMDB page for The Music Lovers

scopecontent.p: An album with approximately 100 colour and black and white photographs from Russell's film The Rainbow , including both scenes from the film and photographs of Russell directing and in breaks from the filming. The album has a dedication: "For Ken, "Thank you for the film that changed my life," lots of love, Clive, 89". The album may well be a gift of Clive Coote, to whom some of the photographs are attributed.

35 black and white photographs of on-stage and behind-the-scenes action from Rakes Progress , a production of the Stravinsky opera, directed by Russell, at the Maggio Musicale festival in Florence in 1982.

An album containing 67 photographs (black and white; colour) relating to Russell's film, Salome's Last Dance , including both scenes from the film and photographs of Russell directing and in breaks from the filming. The album is inscribed as from "Clive", and may well be a gift of Clive Coote, to whom some of the photographs are attributed.

p.extref: IMDB page for Salome's Last Dance

scopecontent.p: Three copies of a booklet (63 p.), Salome , published by Oper der Stadt Bonn. The publication appears to be designed to accompany a production of Richard Strauss' opera Salome , directed by Russell.
Material relating to Ken Russell's film, Savage Messiah , which tells the story of the French sculptor Henri Gaudier-Brzeska.

Detailed contents:
- 133 black and white photographs showing scenes from the film and breaks between filming, including shots of Russell giving direction and of Victoria Russell (age 10), daughter of Ken Russell, who had a role in the film.
- Promotional material for the film: 1 colour photograph, 1 MGM Pressbook, 2 small posters, 1 sheet titled 'Press & Advertising Material for MGM's Savage Messiah.'

did.unittitle: The Strange Affliction of Anton Bruckner

scopecontent.p: Photographs relating to Ken Russell's film The Strange Affliction of Anton Bruckner . All photographs show Russell directing the film. There are two large (approximately 40 x 30 cm) black and white photographs and 4 small (approximately 15 x 10 cm) colour photographs.

p.extref: IMDB page for The Strange Affliction of Anton Bruckner

scopecontent.p: Material relating to Ken Russell's film Tommy . There are 10 black and white photographs showing scenes from the film or during breaks in filming, including some of Russell. There is also a colour program to accompany the film.
Material relating to Ken Russell's film Treasure Island , which was broadcast by Channel 4 in 1995.

Detailed contents:
- A typed 'first draft script', 1 June 1995.
- What appears to be a draft for a promotional booklet for the film, including a synopsis, short biographies of key cast and crew.
- A notebook containing a handwritten version of the script.

did.unittitle: Two Women and a Horse, or, St Mawr

scopecontent.p: A typewritten script for a screenplay entitled Two Women and a Horse by Ken Russell. It is based on D. H. Lawrence's novella St Mawr .

Photographs relating to Ken Russell's film Valentino . There are eight colour photographs that appear to be promotional material, and two black and white photographs of the filming, one showing Russell.
Material relating to Ken Russell's film, Women in Love .

- 21 black and white photographs taken during filming, some apparently showing scenes from the film, others showing the filming process.
- Promotional material for the film: 4 colour promotional photographs, 1 promotional booklet ("Exhibitor's Campaign Book"), 1 sheet showing various different advertisements.

p.extref: IMDB page for Women in Love

scopecontent.p: Still photographs taken by Russell during his time as a professional photographer. There are cuttings from magazines ( Illustrated and The Sketch ) containing his photographs, and one black and white photograph.

arrangement.p: The items are filed under: Ken Russell: friends and family.

scopecontent.p: Material not closely connected to any of Russell's TV and film works. Includes photographs Russell's family and friends, a letter, and newspaper clippings and pamphlets that Russell kept.
Various photographs owned by Russell that do not relate to a particular one of his works.

Detailed contents:
- Five black and white promotional photographs of Dorothy Lamour, taken from her works.
- One black and white photograph of Ken Russell with director Jack Gold, apparently on stage at a conference.
- Two black and white photographs, apparently of a shop window display about Ken Russell.

arrangement.p: The items are filed under: Ken Russell: friends and family.

scopecontent.p: A letter written to Mr Russell from Joanne Deacon (dated 21.03.94); it appears to have originally accompanied a work for Russell to read.

arrangement.p: Items filed under: Ken Russell: Friends and Family

scopecontent.p: Magazines, brochures, and pamphlets relating to the film industry, including: Critics Choice , programmes from the National Film Theatre, the New Cinema Club, the London Film Festival.

arrangement.p: Held in a box in drawer 4.

scopecontent.p: Three empty film tins, one reel of film, one light, one clapperboard.

arrangement.p: Held in a box in drawer 4.

scopecontent.p: A newspaper poster for The Sun (Melbourne), approximately 70 x 50 cm, displaying the headline "Spoleto Nudity Shock" and dated Friday, September 12, 1986. It must related to the Spoleto Festival, held in Melbourne for the first time in 1986, at which Russell was an exhibitor.

arrangement.p: Items filed under: Ken Russell: Friends and Family
